desc: AMER1, a tumor suppressor involved in WNT signaling, is inactivated by mutation or deletion in various cancers, most frequently in colorectal cancer.

The AMER1 (APC membrane recruitment 1) protein was first identified as an APC-binding protein that regulates the cellular localization of the APC tumor suppressor, thereby regulating APC-dependent cellular morphogenesis, cell migration and cell-cell adhesion (PMID: 17925383, 20843316, 27462415). AMER1 also functions as a negative regulator of WNT/β-catenin signaling (PMID: 21248786, 17510365, 20843316). In this capacity, AMER1 acts as a scaffold protein by assembling β-catenin and members of the destruction complex at the plasma membrane, which is necessary for β-catenin degradation (PMID: 17510365, 21498506). The AMER1 gene is mutated in approximately 5-10% of Wilms tumors, a pediatric kidney cancer (PMID: 17204608, 21248786, 19137020, 18311776, 26274016). Missense and truncating AMER1 mutations are found in approximately 7-10% of colorectal cancers and correlate with reduced WNT signaling (PMID: 26071483). This data is consistent with AMER1 functioning as a tumor suppressor, as loss of AMER1 results in activation of WNT/ β-catenin signaling (PMID: 17510365, 17510365).
